desc: Mustaml is a html template language that enforces "logic-less" templates as known from {{ mustache }} but using pythonish indentation like HAML to build html-tags. Here are some Examples of Mustaml usage.

unittests.title: Creating HTML-tags quickly
unittests.desc: You can create tags with the %tag styntax. Nesting is done via indentation. Tags are automatically closed.

unittests.title: Creating HTML-tags even quicker
unittests.desc: You can append child nodes directly to save lines:

unittests.title: Mixing nesting and appending
unittests.desc: For every node you append, we're nesting all child nodes that level deeper. This happens when mixing appending and nesting:

unittests.title: Adding classes and ids in CSS-syntax
unittests.desc: One of the Key features is quickly adding the common class and id attributes, with a syntax well known from CSS.

unittests.title: Implicit Divs
unittests.desc: To make things even easier, you can leave out %tag and Mustaml will guess it's a %div

unittests.title: Generating a Doctype
unittests.desc: Mustaml provides the short triple-bang for inserting your doctype declaration. It currently supports only the HTML5 one.

unittests.title: Self-Closing tags
unittests.desc: You can configure a list of tags that should be self-closed when empty. Here are the defaults:

unittests.title: HTML-Attributes
unittests.desc: Attributes are defined as usual but are appended in brackets. Yes, this is HTML-syntax and not some language-specific map with lots of :, @, => and so on.
unittests.html: Yo!

unittests.title: Old-School HTML-Attributes
unittests.desc: You can use some alternate syntax and whitepace as you like:
unittests.html: Yo!

unittests.title: Overriding HTML-Attributes
unittests.desc: When you specify id attributes in your attribute hash, it is overridden by the latter.

unittests.title: HTML-Array-Attributes
unittests.desc: Some attributes can have a space-separated list of values. Currently these 3 are supported.
unittests.html: <link class="foo bar" rev="prev index" rel="shortlink home up" />

unittests.title: HTML-Comments
unittests.desc: You can insert html-comments too.

unittests.title: HTML-Comment-blocks
unittests.desc: End even put whole parts of your template into comment tags. This might come in handy if you don't want your users to see this part, but be able to check the rendering output.

unittests.title: Inserting Data
unittests.desc: Of course a template engine does output strings. They are escaped for HTML-output by default.

unittests.title: Undefined Data
unittests.desc: If you do not provide a piece of data, it will be silently ignored.

unittests.title: Inserting More Data
unittests.desc: You can define text and vars as children.  (The = tag doesn't want sub-nodes. )

unittests.title: Looping
unittests.desc: The minus operator (-) marks special blocks that behave depending on the var content. For arrays the block will be looped. The current value is available as ".".

unittests.title: Looping Maps
unittests.desc: And you can loop over arrays containing maps. Inside the loop, you can access the map keys like normal vars.

unittests.title: Boolean Switches
unittests.desc: You can check for true/false values with the very same syntax.

unittests.title: Boolean Switches (false)
unittests.desc: A caret operator (^) indicates not, so the children are only shown if the value is false.

unittests.title: Boolean Switches (false positive)
unittests.desc: Consequently, the text is not rendered, if you get a true value after the caret.

unittests.title: Boolean Switches (false positive)
unittests.desc: Another use of the caret is checking for unset values.

unittests.title: Empty Loops
unittests.desc: Another use of the caret is checking for empty arrays, strings and 0 numbers.

unittests.title: Checking for empty Loops
unittests.desc: The notayim operator (^^) will inverse the not-operator. You can check if a loop would render at least one item. In this example the <ul> tag is only rendered if there are any "planets".

unittests.title: Empty-loop-check does nothing when loop has items
unittests.desc: I you use the  notayim operator on an defined value it will just render its subblocks as nothing had happended.

unittests.title: Checking for empty Strings
unittests.desc: The notayim operator (^^) can be used to check if a String is "" (empty). In this example no paragraph is created if the string is empty.

unittests.title: Empty-string-check does nothing when string has chars
unittests.desc: If the string is not empty the subblock remains unaffected and is rendered as usual.

unittests.title: Escaping
unittests.desc: If you want to start a text line with a meta-character otherwise interpreted as some kind of node, you can escape it with a backslash.

unittests.title: Printing verbatim HTML
unittests.desc: The minus operator applied on string values prints them verbatim. Say you've preprocessed some Markdown and want to display it on a page, just insert the string value's varname after the minus.

unittests.title: Using anything (e.g. Strings) with blocks
unittests.desc: Don't get the above confused with calling blocks with Strings. You can use every type of value to initialize blocks, it won't be rendered but it will be availible as "." inside the block.

unittests.title: Using srtings with with blocks vs notayim
unittests.desc: However, other than the notayim-operator, using only minus it will render its block for empty strings too.

unittests.title: Attributes with data
unittests.desc: You can provide a map for highly dynamic attributes, while still defining others in your template. Last specified overrides.

unittests.title: Attributes with data-values
unittests.desc: You can even fill only the attribute's values with dynamic strings, and mix this with other attributes and old syntax. Note that you have to use separators (space or comma) to end the varname string and the attribute value string.

unittests.title: Attributes with data-values and text
unittests.desc: You can mix usal text and dynamic values in your attributes. This is why you have to use separators to end the varname string and the attribute value string.

unittests.title: Attributes with equal signs in them
unittests.desc: To avoid parsing the equal sings as vars just quote the attribute value.

unittests.title: Mustaml-Comments
unittests.desc: Mustaml-Comments are not rendered at all.

unittests.title: Mustaml-Comment-blocks
unittests.desc: Get rid of whole subtrees with Mustaml-Comments.
